Problem:
Consider a complex function defined as \( z(t) = e^{At} x \), where \( x \) is a complex vector and \( A \) is a complex square matrix. Evaluate the effect of applying an integral transformation \( I(z) = \int_0^T e^{Bt}z(t) dt \), where \( B \) is another complex matrix, on this function over a period \( T \).

If \( I(z) \) is computed after \( z(t) \) has evolved up to time \( T \) without any other operations, does the result solely depend on the initial vector \( x \) and the matrices \( A \) and \( B \)?
Explanation: The outcome of \( I(z) \) under these circumstances is directly influenced by \( x \), \( A \), and \( B \) through the integration and matrix exponentials. The linearity and continuity of the integral and exponential operators ensure that the influence of \( x \), \( A \), and \( B \) is straightforwardly propagated through \( z(t) \) to \( I(z) \).
